tooltip.title: Location page header
tooltip.body:
Our  five-color COVID risk level looks at three things: daily new cases (per 100K), infection rate, and positive test rate. Each is graded on a five-color scale and the highest risk color becomes the location’s overall risk level.

For instance, if daily new cases and test positivity are both yellow, but infection rate is orange, then the overall risk level is orange.

[Learn more about COVID risk levels](https://covidactnow.org/covid-risk-levels-metrics).

tooltip.title: Daily new cases
tooltip.body:
Daily new cases, also known as incidence, is the number of new COVID cases  emerging each day in a location. This is measured by the number of positive test results, and it does not include individuals who are infected but asymptomatic or never get tested. 

We generally see daily new cases of zero for several consecutive months in countries that have successfully contained COVID and are now operating at normal levels of activity, such as Taiwan, New Zealand, and Australia.

[Learn more about daily new cases](https://covidactnow.org/covid-risk-levels-metrics#daily-new-cases).

tooltip.title: Infection rate
tooltip.body:
Infection rate, also often referred to as R(t), represents how fast COVID is spreading in a given area right now. Specifically, it estimates the number of people that a single infected person goes on to infect.

For example, an infection rate of 3 estimates  that, in that location, one infected person will infect three other people, and each of those three people will each go on to infect three more people, bringing the total count of infections to 9 people. Eventually, 9 will become 27 and then 81, and so forth.

Daily new cases may be low, but if infection rate is high, then we know that daily new cases will be high in the near future.

We generally see infection rates of zero for several consecutive months in countries that have successfully contained COVID and are now operating at normal levels of activity, such as Taiwan, New Zealand, and Australia.

[Learn more about infection rate](https://covidactnow.org/covid-risk-levels-metrics#infection-rate).

Positive test rate is the percentage of COVID tests that come back positive.

It measures both the severity of COVID and the limitations of testing. Positive test rate can indicate whether a location is getting COVID under control – but only if there is enough testing so that everyone who has COVID is being identified through testing. 

A lower positive test rate means either fewer people are infected or more people are being tested. A higher positive test rate means either more people are infected or fewer people are being tested.

We generally see a positive test rate of less than 1% in countries who have successfully contained COVID and are operating at normal levels of activity, such as Taiwan, New Zealand, and Australia.

[Learn more about positive test rate](https://covidactnow.org/covid-risk-levels-metrics#positive-test-rate).
tooltip.title: Positive test rate

tooltip.body:
ICU capacity used is the percentage of staffed intensive care unit (ICU) beds in a location’s healthcare system that are currently in use by both COVID and non-COVID patients.

The ICU is the part of a hospital for people who are really sick and each ICU bed is equipped with special equipment that regular hospitals don’t have, such as ventilators. ICU beds are important because they may be the difference between life and death for people, including both COVID patients, and other patients, such as those who have had a heart attack.

Experts indicate that during pre-pandemic years, average ICU occupancy in U.S. hospitals ranged from 57% to 82%.

[Learn more about ICU capacity used](https://covidactnow.org/covid-risk-levels-metrics#icu-capacity-used).
tooltip.title: ICU capacity used

tooltip.body:
Percent vaccinated is the percentage of people in a given location that have started the vaccination process by receiving at least their first shot.

[Learn more about percent vaccinated](https://covidactnow.org/covid-risk-levels-metrics#percent-vaccinated).
